rules.title: <cmd>
rules.abstract: Commands are instructions in steps. They tell users what to do in an active voice.

rule-statement.action: Group all actions that tell users how to get to an interface into a single <cmd>.

ul.li: It's a step that represents a single goal. It's as if we said: First, get there!.
It's easy for users to follow simple instructions until the system reacts.
A step for each click would result in tasks with too many steps. Best practices recommend 7 + or - 2 steps per task.

examplefig.codeblock: <steps> <step> <cmd>In <menucascade><uicontrol >Menu</uicontrol><uicontrol >Documents</uicontrol><uicontrol >Transformation</uicontrol></menucascade>, select <uicontrol>XSLT</uicontrol> and click <uicontrol >Modify</uicontrol>.</cmd> <stepresult>The system displays the <uicontrol>Modify XSLT</uicontrol> page.</stepresult> </step> <step> <cmd>Make your changes and click <uicontrol >OK</uicontrol>.</cmd> <info><table conref="fielddescriptions.dita#table" /></info> <stepresult>The system registers the changes.</stepresult> </step> </steps>

rule.rule-statement: When commands reference multiple <uicontrol>, mention the controls in the order in which users see/use them.
rule.justification: Users act as they read. Don't make them scan the commands back and forth to find what they need to click, enter or select next.

rule.rule-statement: When users must fill form fields then limit the content of <cmd> to asking users to fill the form and use <info> to define the fields that are non-trivial, or provide field descriptions for developers to include as tips in application interfaces.

examplefig.desc: Instructing users on how to select each control or fill each field individually results in too many steps.
examplefig.codeblock: <steps> <step> <cmd>Go to <menu-cascade><uicontrol >menu</uicontrol><uicontrol>submenu item</uicontrol><uicontrol>other submenu item</uicontrol></menu-cascade>.</cmd> <stepresult>The page <uicontrol>All changes</uicontrol> is displayed.</stepresult> </step> <step> <cmd>Select item x</cmd> </step> <step> <cmd>Click <uicontrol>Modify item</uicontrol></cmd> </step> <step> <cmd>In field A, enter your A.</cmd> </step> <step> <cmd>In field B, enter your B.</cmd> </step> <step> <cmd>In field C, enter your C.</cmd> </step> <step> <cmd>Click <uicontrol>OK</uicontrol>.</cmd> </step> </steps>
